title: The Living World: Adaptations and Classification

lessons.title: Adaptation
lessons.content:
# Adaptation

Gradual changes occur in the body parts and also in the behaviour of organisms which help them to adjust to their surroundings. Such changes are called adaptations. They take place over a long period of time.

## Adaptation in Aquatic Plants

Some of the aquatic plants are firmly rooted in the soil at the bottom of the water bodies. Their stems are submerged, while leaves and flowers float on the surface. However, some plants are entirely afloat. Their roots are not anchored in the soil.

The surfaces of leaves and stems of many aquatic plants are covered with a waxy layer. Leaves of some aquatic plants are thin and slender like a ribbon. This shape helps them to withstand fast currents of water. Air spaces in stems and petioles of aquatic plants are useful for floating in water.

lessons.title: Adaptation in Desert Plants
lessons.content:
# Adaptation in Desert Plants

Take two potted plants - one a cactus and the other a leafy plant. Tie plastic bags loosely around the leaves of these plants and keep them in sunlight from early in the morning. In the afternoon, bring those pots into the classroom and observe them.

Has the same quantity of water collected in both bags? Neither do desert plants have leaves or they are very small or they are modified into thorns. As a result, they lose very little water by evaporation. The stem stores water and food and is therefore fleshy. The stems are green as they perform photosynthesis in the absence of leaves. Their roots penetrate deep into the soil in search of water. There is a thick layer of a waxy substance on the stems of these plants, too.

lessons.title: Classification of Living Organisms
lessons.content:
# Classification of Living Organisms

It is difficult to study and remember all the organisms in this diverse living world at the same time. Classification helps in this respect. Different scientists have used different criteria and independently classified plants and animals. A hierarchy is formed in the classification that starts with Kingdom Animalia or Kingdom Plantae; further groups and sub-groups are formed depending upon basic similarities and differences. This is called the 'hierarchy of classification'.

## Binomial Nomenclature by Carl Linnaeus

Imagine that there are four students with a name 'Kabir' or 'Kiran' in a classroom. If you talk about 'Kabir' or 'Kiran' in class, how will you ensure that others understand which one of them you are talking about? We shall mention their full names, i.e., the first name and the last name. This is similar to binomial nomenclature.

Binomial nomenclature is used to identify each organism. Accordingly, a scientific name has been assigned to each organism. It consists of two parts - the first part is 'Genus' and the second, 'Species'. All identified organisms have been assigned a binomial name as per the guidelines of the International Code of Nomenclature.

questions.question: What are gradual changes that help organisms adjust to their surroundings called?
questions.explanation: Gradual changes that help organisms adjust to their surroundings are called adaptations.

questions.question: Why do desert plants have thorns?
questions.explanation: Leaves are modified into thorns to reduce water loss by evaporation.

questions.question: Who introduced Binomial Nomenclature?
questions.explanation: Binomial Nomenclature was introduced by Carl Linnaeus.

questions.question: Why do aquatic plants have air spaces in their stems?
questions.explanation: Air spaces in stems help aquatic plants float in water.

questions.question: What is the waxy layer on desert plants used for?
questions.explanation: The waxy layer helps prevent water loss through evaporation.

questions.question: In binomial nomenclature, what does the first part represent?
questions.explanation: In binomial nomenclature, the first part represents the Genus.

questions.question: Why are the stems of desert plants green?
questions.explanation: Desert plant stems are green because they perform photosynthesis in the absence of leaves.

questions.question: What shape are the leaves of some aquatic plants to withstand water currents?
questions.explanation: Thin, ribbon-like leaves help aquatic plants withstand fast water currents.

questions.question: Where do desert plant roots penetrate to find water?
questions.explanation: Desert plant roots penetrate deep into the soil in search of water.

questions.question: What is the purpose of classification of living organisms?
options: To study and remember them easily
questions.explanation: Classification helps to study and remember organisms easily by organizing them into groups based on similarities.
